answers.text: A branch of computer science focused on improving the quality of digital images and videos
A method used to enhance the quality in multimedia applications
The field of study that enables computers to interpret and understand visual information from the world
The process of developing algorithms for natural language processing and text analysis

questions.text: What is the best definition of computer vision?

answers.text: The system ensures that only fans who purchased tickets online can enter the stadium, which has no ethical implications
Privacy concerns arise as the biometric data is collected and stored, potentially leading to misuse or unauthorized sharing of personal information
Enhanced security measures help prevent ticket fraud and improve the overall safety of attendees, though it may inconvenience some fans
Facial recognition technology is primarily used to display personalized advertisements, which involves ethical considerations about sharing personal choices

questions.text:
Evaluate the possible ethical implications in the following scenario– 

A fan of a sports team gets scanned by a facial recognition device before being able to enter the stadium to see their team play.

answers.text: Implement a computer vision system to monitor customer interactions with products, analyzing patterns to predict demand and optimize inventory levels
Develop a computer vision application that tracks the attendance and work hours of employees to improve staffing efficiency
Use a computer vision system to track the overall foot traffic in the shop and provide weekly reports on customer visits
Install computer vision cameras to monitor and enhance the lighting and ambiance within the shop to create a more inviting environment for customers

questions.text:
Propose a sample solution to the following scenario that best utilizes computer vision–

A shop keeper is worried that she might have bought too much merchandise.

answers.text: An edge detection algorithm enhances image resolution, making finer details visible for better analysis
An edge detection algorithm is primarily used for tracking color changes across an image
An edge detection algorithm improves image compression by reducing the file size of images
An edge detection algorithm can identify object boundaries in images, aiding in object recognition and scene understanding

questions.text: Examine how an edge detection algorithm might be employed with computer vision systems

answers.text: Pixels are small dots in an image, each holding a single value representing the intensity of light at that point
Pixels are the smallest units of a digital image, represented as individual points with specific color values defined by combinations of red, green, and blue (RGB)
Pixels are clusters of multiple points, each representing a different section of an image
Pixels are lines of data that form the edges of shapes within an image

questions.text: Describe the way that pixels are represented in digital images

answers.text: Encoding URLs for quick access to websites
Providing details about products and services

questions.text: Determine which of the following is not a common usage of QR codes in computer vision applications:

answers.text: The lighting conditions in the room are too bright, causing the system to malfunction
The computer vision system needs higher resolution images to correctly identify small objects like a candy bar
The COCO dataset may not include specific categories or images of the particular candy bar, leading to poor recognition performance
The camera being used is incompatible with the computer vision system, resulting in faulty image capture

questions.text:
Assess the following scenario and propose a possible reason why the user is not getting the result that they want–

A computer vision system was trained using the COCOS dataset in order to perform object recognition. Upon testing, a user noticed that it was not able to properly identify the candy bar that she was holding up.

answers.text: Using a balanced dataset with an equal number of images for each category, because it prevents the model from being biased towards one category
Using labeled images with clear annotations, because it ensures the model learns from accurate data
Using a diverse dataset with images from different environments, because it increases the ability of the model to generalize
Using images with poor lighting and/or low resolution, because they provide unclear and insufficient details for accurate model training

questions.text: Identify which of the following methods might lead to the least useful data when training a model and explain why.

answers.text: Use a single high-resolution image of the known dog to train the model, as it will focus on detailed features
Train the model using images of different dog breeds to improve its generalization capabilities, even if they are not the target dog
Use a pre-trained model on generic dog images and fine-tune it with a few images of the known dog, so it will perform well
Collect a diverse dataset with images of the known dog in various lighting conditions, poses, and backgrounds to ensure the model recognizes the dog accurately in different situations

questions.text:
Compose a plan that would best eliminate bias in the following scenario–
A inventor would like to create a doggy door application that utilizes computer vision in order to only open when a known dog is identified.

answers.text: Training a model to distinguish between different species of birds using photos
Predicting future weather patterns based on images of historical weather features
Developing a model to identify various hand gestures using video input
Creating a model to recognize different spoken commands using audio samples

https://studio.code.org/s/computer-visio.long_instructions:
# The Search for Pixel Pixel the cat, the beloved pet of the mayor of CeeVeeville, has gone missing! You have been hired to become a digital detective and to help bring the feline back home. In this activity, you will examine a variety of different locations/scenes within the city, using computer vision techniques to help solve Pixel’s strange disappearance. How to Navigate Through the Activity

Make sure to use slideshow mode on the slide in order to be able to click and interact with icons, images, and hotspots. This is found on the upper-right corner of Google Slides. If accessed through this level, the activity will default to slideshow mode.


Use the main city map to navigate to different locations in order to investigate the scene. Clicking any of the icons with the red dashed border will navigate you to that scene. Different locations will appear depending on the round of the activity.


Each scene contains a visual image of what you find there. There are often different views within each scene. You can navigate through these views by using the view menu on the right-hand side of the screen.


Click the map icon to return to the main city map in order to visit another location.


To learn about what computer vision technique can be used in the scene, click the question mark icon.


To apply the computer vision technique within the scene, click the magnifying glass icon.


Each scene is also a puzzle – it will require you to interact with the image in order to find clues to help solve the mystery. Clicking specific places on the image will result in clues surfacing and allowing you to follow on the trail of Pixel the cat.

# Introduction to Computer Vision Reflection

### What is your definition of computer vision?

**Use the space below to answer the above prompt**

[][0]
https://studio.code.org/s/computer-visio.teacher_markdown:
Allows students to share what they have constructed as their working definition of computer vision thus far. This definition is sure to evolve and grow as the module progresses. Some possible examples for a working definition might include:

-   Computer vision is like when your computer tries to figure out what's in a picture, kind of like how we recognize our friends' faces or stuff in photos
-   Computer vision helps computers 'see' and understand the images and videos like we do, but through cameras and algorithms
-   It's like teaching a computer to see and interpret the world around it, so it can recognize objects, people, and even actions
-   It's a part of artificial intelligence where computers are trained to interpret and understand the visual world

dsls.description: While the usage of computer vision will grow at a rapid pace and transform the whole healthcare industry, how is computer vision used today? Explore one of the ways below:
dsls.display_name: Computer Vision in Action in Healthcare

CV_CareerExploration3_3a_2024.bubble_choice_description: Explore how computers are aiding in making medical diagnoses using a variety of imaging platforms.
CV_CareerExploration3_3a_2024.long_instructions:
##The Details
In healthcare, computer aided detection (CADe) and computer-aided diagnosis (CADx) refer to any applications in which a computer assists a doctor or in understanding and evaluating medical data. Within the context of computer vision, this typically means images coming from MRI, CT, X-ray, or another form of diagnostic imaging technique. However, CAD can even be (and has been) applied to camera images of faces.

Computers can assist doctors in detection by identifying suspicious regions in images and alerting the physician to these concerning areas. In some cases, CADe amounts to predicting high confidence regions of interest and projecting bounding boxes for these regions onto the original image. In other cases, region of interest identification is followed by instance segmentation. In still other cases, anomaly detection may be applied to catch abnormalities.

Computer-aided diagnosis takes images and other patient record information as input, and outputs evaluates the likelihood that the patient has a given disease or condition. In cancer diagnosis, for instance, this often means predicting whether a tumor is benign or malignant.


![](https://images.code.org/69283df78ff42617c6fa1dd3165f58f1-image-1719521635931.png)

##Explore further
Timer permitting, click this link to explore this and other computer vision solutions more in-depth: [Computer Vision in Healthcare](https://medium.com/voxel51/how-computer-vision-is-changing-healthcare-in-2023-e49d63d9922f).

*What is your opinion-- is this an effective and trusted use of computer vision within the health industry?*
CV_CareerExploration3_3a_2024.title: Computer Vision in Healthcare: Computer-Aided Detection

CV_CareerExploration3_3b_2024.bubble_choice_description: How can computer vision allow healthcare workers to track and adapt to how different diseases progress?
CV_CareerExploration3_3b_2024.long_instructions:
##The Details
Computer vision can be used to precisely monitor the progression of a disease over time. Just as a doctor measures patient weight, height, and blood pressure during an exam, and compares these to the patient’s past measurements to assess patient health, computer vision models allow doctors to track various diseases by comparing markers in biomedical images taken at different points in time.

In some applications, progression can be monitored by precisely tracking the size of objects like cavities or lesions. More generally, computer vision applications in disease progression monitoring are characterized by a deep learning model assigning a numerical score to an image or video. These scores allow physicians to quantify the severity and time of onset for a specific patient.

By precisely monitoring progression, computer vision models can help physicians to detect the onset of a disease more rapidly. For glaucoma, a 2018 study concluded that deep learning accelerated time to detection by more than a year.

While computer vision applications in disease monitoring primarily involve applying machine learning models to images, there are also applications involving video data. In a 2022 paper, researchers found that by evaluating the movement patterns of Parkinson’s disease patients in the act of rising from a chair, the researchers could robustly estimate disease severity. To interpret patient movement, the researchers estimated patient pose in each frame, and then quantified the velocity and smoothness of motion across video frames.


![](https://images.code.org/b05fc0fa2e91308574685f8f3d39bb7f-image-1719522066641.png)
##Explore further
Timer permitting, click this link to explore this and other computer vision solutions more in-depth: [Computer Vision in Healthcare](https://medium.com/voxel51/how-computer-vision-is-changing-healthcare-in-2023-e49d63d9922f).

*What is your opinion-- is this an effective and trusted use of computer vision within the healthcare industry?*
CV_CareerExploration3_3b_2024.title: Computer Vision in Healthcare: Disease Progression

CV_CareerExploration3_3c_2024.bubble_choice_description: Computer vision is used in planning for and carrying out a variety of different surgeries.
CV_CareerExploration3_3c_2024.long_instructions:
##The Details

Computer vision is deeply entrenched in the history of planning for surgery: CT scans and other forms of diagnostic imaging make possible the construction of anatomical models. This imaging data is used to generate 2D projections called templates, 3D digital reconstructions, or even 3D printed models. The models then allow surgeons to explore various approaches and entry pathways prior to surgery, minimizing time of surgery and invasiveness.

In recent years, the application of emerging technologies like deep learning and virtual reality in preoperative planning has begun to streamline surgery even further. According to a recent study involving 193 knee surgery cases, AI-based preoperative planning has the potential to reduce the average number of intraoperative corrections a surgeon needs to make by up to 50%.

In image-guided surgery, a surgeon uses this real time visual and spatial information to navigate with enhanced precision. This technology is at the heart of minimally invasive surgical (MIS) procedures. Images taken during surgery can also be fused with preoperative images in augmented reality environments.

While still far from common, we are also beginning to see computer vision-enabled navigation, AI-driven decision making, and robotic maneuverability come together in partially and even fully autonomous robotic surgical systems.

![](https://images.code.org/64cd54d9cd1012a358d519b130bc7372-image-1719522677947.png)
##Explore further
Timer permitting, click this link to explore this and other computer vision solutions more in-depth: [Computer Vision in Healthcare](https://medium.com/voxel51/how-computer-vision-is-changing-healthcare-in-2023-e49d63d9922f).

*What is your opinion-- is this an effective and trusted use of computer vision within the healthcare industry?*
CV_CareerExploration3_3c_2024.title: Computer Vision in Healthcare: Surgery

CV_CareerExploration3_3d_2024.bubble_choice_description: Assistive technologies help patients with a variety of different needs to become more self-sufficient.
CV_CareerExploration3_3d_2024.long_instructions:
##The Details


In many applications of computer vision, AI models are employed to take on tasks in order to free up humans from tedious or hazardous work. Perhaps nowhere is computer vision’s liberating effect on people more pronounced than in assisting people with vision loss. Computer vision makes it easier for them to live on their own and attend work and school.

Computer Vision technology can assistby providing audio descriptions of their surroundings, identifying objects, and helping them navigate their environment. In the same way, Augmented Reality technology provides people with physical disabilities with real-time assistance and information about their environment, making it easier for them to perform tasks and navigate unfamiliar places.

![](https://images.code.org/6f61b787675296b259df9eddeae96907-image-1719523430991.png)

##Explore further
Timer permitting, click this link to explore this and other computer vision solutions more in-depth: [Computer Vision in Healthcare](https://medium.com/voxel51/how-computer-vision-is-changing-healthcare-in-2023-e49d63d9922f).

*What is your opinion-- is this an effective and trusted use of computer vision within the healthcare industry?*
CV_CareerExploration3_3d_2024.title: Computer Vision in Healthcare: Assistive Technologies

## How Can Computer Vision Further Assist Healthcare Workers?

Now that you have explored some of the ways in which computer vision is expanding within the healthcare industry, use your knowledge to help problem-solve.

The following were identified as some of the main issues associated with the modern healthcare system:

-   **Rising costs of healthcare**
-   **Shortage of healthcare workers**
-   **Time-intensive records keeping**

With a partner, focus on one healthcare profession and brainstorm a possible way in which one or more of the computer vision techniques listed below might assist help to address one of the major issues in healthcare currently. If you need help selected, a list of healthcare professions can be [here][0]

-   The name of the healthcare-related job
-   What major healthcare issue will be addressing?

[][0]
https://studio.code.org/s/computer-visio.teacher_markdown: The goal here is to encourage students to think broadly about the roles of education, transparency, public engagement and perhaps even policy in addressing ethical challenges. [][0]
https://studio.code.org/s/computer-visio.teacher_markdown: This question aims to personalize the ethical considerations of computer vision technologies, prompting students to reflect on and articulate their values and priorities. The goal is to foster a deeper understanding of the diverse ethical dimensions these technologies entail, such as privacy, consent, transparency, and accountability. By identifying and discussing the most pressing ethical issue from their perspective, students can explore the rationale behind ethical guidelines and the potential consequences of overlooking these considerations.

dsls.description: Explore the jobs of the future by seeing how computer vision might aid, enhance, or redefine professions. Below are interviews from a variety of people who work as Design/Creative Technologists, utilizing varied computer vision applications to aid in the interactivity of their work. All interviews are excerpted from https://www.creativelivesinprogress.com/job-roles/creative-technologist

CV_CareerExploration1_2d_2024.bubble_choice_description: Johanna Jaskowska’s hyper-shiny, highlight-perfect Instagram face filters have experienced viral success since the beginning of this year.
CV_CareerExploration1_2d_2024.long_instructions:
##How do you describe what you do?
I’m a weird hybrid creative, but ‘digital creative’ is the umbrella that captures all the skills I use. I have a design and art direction background so I can do a bit of everything, including some developing, focusing on new media and technologies and innovations. My main focus, though, is concept: if there’s no story, none of the work makes sense. I find a lot of brands get into using augmented reality (AR) but they don't always understand the purpose of these technologies.

##How did you go about creating your first filters?
When I published my first filter, I had to shape the face of the users in a plastic material in order to cast light on the face. From the users feedback I realised that the thing that folks were talking about was the plastic effect. It says a lot about society (smooth skin, perfect, the idea that everything has to be sleek without imperfection). It also really attracts the eye, like looking at the reflection of water.

I thought ‘OK I’ll make the 100% plastic face filter.’ That’s how I got the idea to make Beauty 3000, I just exaggerated it. And when I did it, I was really surprised with the result, even on my own face. It’s important to understand social media and how people use it, so if you hide the face people don’t have the space to tell the story of themselves, and people like to talk about themselves.

![](https://images.code.org/1f838b37f886de8d45ad48f63ddc64c4-image-1719432734642.png)

##Have you had any surprising moments since the filters went viral?
It was very intense – I didn’t expect any of it and I had to learn a lot. The social media pressure was overwhelming, so many people contacted me for interviews, work or features, it was too much and it was very difficult to handle everything. I was trying to respond to everyone but I realised I needed to think about myself, so I slowed down and I’m learning to say no...

What I find so fascinating with AR is when it’s actually impossible in real life – you can play with physics, textures, you can wear imagery or a dress that is like wood or water.

##How useful were your studies to the work you do now?
I had a hard time after my studies when I was looking for a ‘real job’ to define myself as either a designer or art director or developer. I didn’t want to be categorised. I chose the digital field because I'm very curious and I knew the field would continue to fascinate me and that there would always be something new. I knew I’d be captivated and have food for my brain.
CV_CareerExploration1_2d_2024.placeholder: What do you notice? What do you wonder?
CV_CareerExploration1_2d_2024.title: Johanna Jaskowska Interview

CV_CareerExploration1_2b_2024.bubble_choice_description: Creative technologist and dancer Mélanie Chappuis takes inspiration from the moving parts of the world: from flora and fauna, to the human body, and fuses it into her code.
CV_CareerExploration1_2b_2024.long_instructions:
##How would you describe what you do as Creative Technologist?
As a creative technologist, I’m interested in the intersection between art and technology. I create immersive sensory experiences to better engage and reconnect people, including those with disabilities. I explore new perspectives in Human-Computer Interaction especially concerning how the body can be an interface to learning and creativity.

Movement and dance are important elements of my practice, they are some of the most liberating ways to express our feelings. I’ve created a series of web experiments exploring the relationship between movement and machine, in which you can use your body as a musical instrument. I had the chance to showcase my work at the Secret Art Gallery and many other galleries in London with the participation of talented dancers.

##Can you tell us about some of your favourite projects to date?
A project I was proud to be part of was the launch of the AW22 collection for Zara. With the engineering and design team, I created an immersive pop-up... The installation presents a video projection of the new products, which you can interact with. The type of interaction I've explored with machine learning [computer vision] is called image recognition. Depending on the pose you’re making, it shows different articles of clothing projected onto your body.

![](https://images.code.org/94607b1b909617ed1319ec7f0c42573c-image-1719433556278.png)

##What skills or traits are most essential to the role?
I did an MSc in Creative Computing to have a solid base in coding and understand which [programming languages] I would like to use and develop in my art. It’s also important to always be open to learning new programming languages because things move fast in the tech world, and new forms of creativity can appear at any time.

I knew from the beginning that art was my passion. Since I was a kid, I was already painting and making music in the Swiss countryside. But I also gravitated toward math and science because I loved the logic and feeling of progressive problem-solving.
CV_CareerExploration1_2b_2024.placeholder: What do you notice? What do you wonder?
CV_CareerExploration1_2b_2024.title: Mélanie Chappuis Interview

CV_CareerExploration1_2c_2024.bubble_choice_description: Just a year into her graphic design degree, Maria Than felt lost, low and ready to drop out. That all changed when a university lecturer introduced her to augmented reality – and the rest, as she says, is history.
CV_CareerExploration1_2c_2024.long_instructions:
##How would you describe what you do?
In my design practice, I am the co-founder as well as creative and tech producer at Ricebox Studio, which I run alongside three of my friends – Anna Tsuda, Safiya Ahmed and Bristy Azmi. We’re called Ricebox because all four of us are from different Asian backgrounds (Japanese, Indian, Bengali, Vietnamese) and rice is our common cultural staple! Our mission is to use creative tech and design for social good, and we start conversations on important topics like sustainability and racism through alternative methods of communication. I’m also a part-time digital designer at Child Rights International Network (CRIN), where I work alongside policymakers and researchers to advocate for children’s rights in creative and accessible ways.

##What are you working on lately?
Being a designer... built up my understanding of the current discussions and initiatives surrounding social issues on an international scale. That’s informed Ricebox projects like MUCChase – the AR treasure hunt about fast fashion and sustainability that we developed for the Responsive Fashion Institute – and On Your Side UK, the UK’s first national helpline service for East and Southeast Asian victims of hate crimes and racism, which we shaped the user experience and user interface for.

Meanwhile, my personal ‘sandbox’ of solo projects has really expanded my practice too... creative tech has allowed me to try out new techniques for fun, such as 3D-scanning when creating a video for the musician SpiderPlant. My personal experience as an augmented reality (AR) Instagram filter designer has also fed into how I use AR within storytelling and activism, especially at Ricebox Studio.

![](https://images.code.org/0929f6903497f2b8d8a1adff428a075d-image-1719434122475.png)

##Would you say you need any specific training for what you do?
Yes and no. I graduated with a BA in Graphic Design, which taught me essential design principles, approaches to conceptual development and ways of pitching to clients. However, my skills in creative technologies were really a mix of formal and informal training.

AR was self-taught – in fact, the majority of AR designers I know did not undergo formal training; we all used YouTube tutorials, plus we swapped advice and troubleshooting tips on Facebook groups.

Generative AI, programming, web development and physical computing were a mix. I started off trying to learn it all on my own, but it was an absolute car crash! I lacked diligence, was so confused and had a messy approach to troubleshooting, so I took to learning from people and enrolling in online courses instead.
CV_CareerExploration1_2c_2024.placeholder: What do you notice? What do you wonder?
CV_CareerExploration1_2c_2024.title: Maria Than Interview

dsls.markdown:
##[Optional] Personal Career Exploration

###Do This:
1.  Explore the Occupational Outlook Handbook from the BLS in order to find a career that is interesting to you.
2. Provide relevant statistics about the profession in the spaces provided below
3. Explain one way that computer vision is already being used in the profession OR speculate about one way how computer vision might be incorporated into the profession in the future.

###[Link to Occupational Outlook Handbook](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/)

answers.text: A branch of computer science focused on improving the quality of digital images and videos
A method used to enhance the quality in multimedia applications
The field of study that enables computers to interpret and understand visual information from the world
The process of developing algorithms for natural language processing and text analysis

questions.text: What is the best definition of computer vision?

answers.text: The system ensures that only fans who purchased tickets online can enter the stadium, which has no ethical implications
Privacy concerns arise as the biometric data is collected and stored, potentially leading to misuse or unauthorized sharing of personal information
Enhanced security measures help prevent ticket fraud and improve the overall safety of attendees, though it may inconvenience some fans
Facial recognition technology is primarily used to display personalized advertisements, which involves ethical considerations about sharing personal choices

questions.text:
Evaluate the possible ethical implications in the following scenario– 

A fan of a sports team gets scanned by a facial recognition device before being able to enter the stadium to see their team play.

answers.text: Implement a computer vision system to monitor customer interactions with products, analyzing patterns to predict demand and optimize inventory levels
Develop a computer vision application that tracks the attendance and work hours of employees to improve staffing efficiency
Use a computer vision system to track the overall foot traffic in the shop and provide weekly reports on customer visits
Install computer vision cameras to monitor and enhance the lighting and ambiance within the shop to create a more inviting environment for customers

questions.text:
Propose a sample solution to the following scenario that best utilizes computer vision–

A shop keeper is worried that she might have bought too much merchandise.

answers.text: An edge detection algorithm enhances image resolution, making finer details visible for better analysis
An edge detection algorithm is primarily used for tracking color changes across an image
An edge detection algorithm improves image compression by reducing the file size of images
An edge detection algorithm can identify object boundaries in images, aiding in object recognition and scene understanding

questions.text: Examine how an edge detection algorithm might be employed with computer vision systems

answers.text: Pixels are small dots in an image, each holding a single value representing the intensity of light at that point
Pixels are the smallest units of a digital image, represented as individual points with specific color values defined by combinations of red, green, and blue (RGB)
Pixels are clusters of multiple points, each representing a different section of an image
Pixels are lines of data that form the edges of shapes within an image

questions.text: Describe the way that pixels are represented in digital images

answers.text: Encoding URLs for quick access to websites
Providing details about products and services

questions.text: Determine which of the following is not a common usage of QR codes in computer vision applications:

answers.text: The lighting conditions in the room are too bright, causing the system to malfunction
The computer vision system needs higher resolution images to correctly identify small objects like a candy bar
The COCO dataset may not include specific categories or images of the particular candy bar, leading to poor recognition performance
The camera being used is incompatible with the computer vision system, resulting in faulty image capture

questions.text:
Assess the following scenario and propose a possible reason why the user is not getting the result that they want–

A computer vision system was trained using the COCOS dataset in order to perform object recognition. Upon testing, a user noticed that it was not able to properly identify the candy bar that she was holding up.

answers.text: Using a balanced dataset with an equal number of images for each category, because it prevents the model from being biased towards one category
Using labeled images with clear annotations, because it ensures the model learns from accurate data
Using a diverse dataset with images from different environments, because it increases the ability of the model to generalize
Using images with poor lighting and/or low resolution, because they provide unclear and insufficient details for accurate model training

questions.text: Identify which of the following methods might lead to the least useful data when training a model and explain why.

answers.text: Use a single high-resolution image of the known dog to train the model, as it will focus on detailed features
Train the model using images of different dog breeds to improve its generalization capabilities, even if they are not the target dog
Use a pre-trained model on generic dog images and fine-tune it with a few images of the known dog, so it will perform well
Collect a diverse dataset with images of the known dog in various lighting conditions, poses, and backgrounds to ensure the model recognizes the dog accurately in different situations

questions.text:
Compose a plan that would best eliminate bias in the following scenario–
A inventor would like to create a doggy door application that utilizes computer vision in order to only open when a known dog is identified.

answers.text: Training a model to distinguish between different species of birds using photos
Predicting future weather patterns based on images of historical weather features
Developing a model to identify various hand gestures using video input
Creating a model to recognize different spoken commands using audio samples

questions.text: Identify the scenario below that is least likely to be successful when training a model with Teachable Machine

dsls.markdown:
###Please take a moment to respond to this short survey.

Code.org takes your privacy seriously. Your responses here will be kept **anonymous**. Your teacher can see responses for the whole class but without names attached.
